source.0429e0b9:
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sb
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from datetime import datetime
print("Setup done")
source.a37940e4:
data_knmi = pd.read_csv("../input/knmi-data/knmi.csv",
                        parse_dates=['YYYYMMDD'],
                        date_parser=lambda x: datetime.strptime(x, "%Y%m%d")
                       )
data_knmi.rename(
    columns={'STN':'Station','YYYYMMDD':'Date'},
    inplace=True
)
data_knmi = data_knmi.astype({'TG':'float','TN':'float','TX':'float'})
data_knmi.TG = data_knmi.TG.map(lambda v: v / 10)
data_knmi.TN = data_knmi.TN.map(lambda v: v / 10)
data_knmi.TX = data_knmi.TX.map(lambda v: v / 10)
print("Data preparation done")
source.1605a606:
data = data_knmi.head(365 * 3)

plt.figure(figsize=(24,8))
sb.lineplot(data=data, x="Date", y="TG", color="royalblue")
plt.fill_between(data=data, x="Date", y1="TN", y2="TX", color='royalblue', alpha=.2)
plt.ylabel("Temperture")
plt.legend()
plt.show()
source.18a9edde:
plt.figure(figsize=(20, 8))
sb.regplot(data=data_knmi, x="RH", y="TG")
plt.xlabel("Rain")
plt.ylabel("Temperture")
source.ee2f9250:
## Termperture trends

We can see a patern of termperture throughout the years.

I limited the number of entries to 3 years for readability
source.84fe7397:
## Data preparation

We need to convert the metrics to floats so we can work with actual celcius.

We also need to convert the datestamps to actual date types so we can work with dates.

Renaming our columns will make things more readable.

Last but not least we will divide the temperture values by 10 since they were deliverd to us in .1 celcius.
source.154fb5b5:
## Data

We have a couple of columns here:
 - **Station** - *Weather station*
 - **Date** - *Date on which the data was recoded*
 - **TG, TN, TX & RH** - *These are our metrics*

In the below plotted data we can see that there is hardly a correlation between the rain and the temperture.
